a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[3, 7], [-1, -2]])"
shows  "A^^27 + A^^31 + A^^40 = matrix([[-1, 0], [0, -1]])"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix},\]compute $\mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 7 \\ -1 & -3 \end{pmatrix}\]and \[\mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = -\mathbf{I}.\]Then \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40} &= (\mathbf{A}^3)^9 + (\mathbf{A}^3)^{10} \mathbf{A} + (\mathbf{A}^3)^{13} \mathbf{A} \\ &= (-\mathbf{I})^9 + (-\mathbf{I})^{10} \mathbf{A} + (-\mathbf{I})^{13} \mathbf{A} \\
 &= -\mathbf{I} + \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{A} \\ &= -\mathbf{I} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[3, 7], [-1, -2]])"
shows  "A^^27 + A^^31 + A^^40 = matrix([[-1, 0], [0, -1]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given the 2x2 matrix A = [[3, 7], [-1, -2]], calculate the sum of A raised to the 27th power, A raised to the 31st power, and A raised to the 40th power. The final answer is the 2x2 matrix [[-1, 0], [0, -1]].

a_1.formal problem:
Unfortunately, the Isabelle/HOL theorem prover does not directly support matrix calculations. However, you can encode matrices as functions from a pair of natural numbers to real numbers. Here is an example of how you might represent this problem in Isabelle:

```
typedecl matrix
axiomatization
  A :: "matrix"
and
  mat_pow :: "matrix => nat => matrix"
and
  mat_add :: "matrix => matrix => matrix"
and
  mat_equals :: "matrix => matrix => bool"
where
  A_def: "A = (%(i, j). if i = 1 & j = 1 then 3 else if i = 1 & j = 2 then 7 else if i = 2 & j = 1 then -1 else if i = 2 & j = 2 then -2 else 0)"
and
  mat_pow_def: "!!A n. mat_pow A n = (%(i, j). (if n = 0 then (if i = j then 1 else 0) else A(i, j) ^ n))"
and
  mat_add_def: "!!A B. mat_add A B = (%(i, j). A(i, j) + B(i, j))"
and
  mat_equals_def: "!!A B. mat_equals A B = (!i j. A(i, j) = B(i, j))"
  
theorem final_answer:
  "mat_equals (mat_add (mat_add (mat_pow A 27) (mat_pow A 31)) (mat_pow A 40)) (%(i, j). if i = j then -1 else 0)"
```
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix},\]compute $\mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 7 \\ -1 & -3 \end{pmatrix}\]and \[\mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = -\mathbf{I}.\]Then \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40} &= (\mathbf{A}^3)^9 + (\mathbf{A}^3)^{10} \mathbf{A} + (\mathbf{A}^3)^{13} \mathbf{A} \\ &= (-\mathbf{I})^9 + (-\mathbf{I})^{10} \mathbf{A} + (-\mathbf{I})^{13} \mathbf{A} \\
 &= -\mathbf{I} + \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{A} \\ &= -\mathbf{I} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}}. \end{align}
 *)

Unfortunately, the Isabelle/HOL theorem prover does not directly support matrix calculations. However, you can encode matrices as functions from a pair of natural numbers to real numbers. Here is an example of how you might represent this problem in Isabelle:

```
typedecl matrix
axiomatization
  A :: "matrix"
and
  mat_pow :: "matrix => nat => matrix"
and
  mat_add :: "matrix => matrix => matrix"
and
  mat_equals :: "matrix => matrix => bool"
where
  A_def: "A = (%(i, j). if i = 1 & j = 1 then 3 else if i = 1 & j = 2 then 7 else if i = 2 & j = 1 then -1 else if i = 2 & j = 2 then -2 else 0)"
and
  mat_pow_def: "!!A n. mat_pow A n = (%(i, j). (if n = 0 then (if i = j then 1 else 0) else A(i, j) ^ n))"
and
  mat_add_def: "!!A B. mat_add A B = (%(i, j). A(i, j) + B(i, j))"
and
  mat_equals_def: "!!A B. mat_equals A B = (!i j. A(i, j) = B(i, j))"
  
theorem final_answer:
  "mat_equals (mat_add (mat_add (mat_pow A 27) (mat_pow A 31)) (mat_pow A 40)) (%(i, j). if i = j then -1 else 0)"
```
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Consider a 2x2 matrix A, where the elements of A are defined as follows: A[1,1] = 3, A[1,2] = 7, A[2,1] = -1, A[2,2] = -2. The power of a matrix (A^n) is defined as the matrix with elements A[i,j]^n. The addition of two matrices (A + B) is defined as a matrix with elements A[i,j] + B[i,j].

Is it true that the sum of A to the power of 27, A to the power of 31, and A to the power of 40 equals a 2x2 matrix with all diagonal elements equal to -1 and all off-diagonal elements equal to 0?

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A 0 = matrix([[3::real, 7], [-1, -2]])"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> A n = A (n-1) * A 0"
shows  "A 27 + A 31 + A 40 = matrix([[-1::real, 0], [0, -1]])"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix},\]compute $\mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 7 \\ -1 & -3 \end{pmatrix}\]and \[\mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = -\mathbf{I}.\]Then \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40} &= (\mathbf{A}^3)^9 + (\mathbf{A}^3)^{10} \mathbf{A} + (\mathbf{A}^3)^{13} \mathbf{A} \\ &= (-\mathbf{I})^9 + (-\mathbf{I})^{10} \mathbf{A} + (-\mathbf{I})^{13} \mathbf{A} \\
 &= -\mathbf{I} + \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{A} \\ &= -\mathbf{I} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real^2^2"
assumes h0 : "A 0 = matrix([[3::real, 7], [-1, -2]])"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> A n = A (n-1) * A 0"
shows  "A 27 + A 31 + A 40 = matrix([[-1::real, 0], [0, -1]])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A matrix $A$ is defined recursively by $A(0) = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{bmatrix}$ and $A(n) = A(n-1) \times A(0)$ for all integers $n \geq 1$. Find the value of $A(27) + A(31) + A(40)$. The final answer is $\begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$.

a_3.informal problem: Given a 2x2 matrix A with elements [[3, 7], [-1, -2]], find the sum of the 27th, 31st, and 40th powers of A. The final answer is a 2x2 matrix with elements [[-1, 0], [0, -1]].

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "real mat"
assumes h0 : "A = list_of_list_to_matrix [[3, 7], [-1, -2]]"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. A powr n = (list_of_list_to_matrix [[-1, 0], [0, -1]])"
shows  "A powr 27 + A powr 31 + A powr 40 = list_of_list_to_matrix [[-1, 0], [0, -1]]"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Given
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix},\]compute $\mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40}.$ The final Answer is \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}
 ### Proof
 Note that \[\mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 7 \\ -1 & -3 \end{pmatrix}\]and \[\mathbf{A}^3 = \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix} = -\mathbf{I}.\]Then \begin{align}
 \mathbf{A}^{27} + \mathbf{A}^{31} + \mathbf{A}^{40} &= (\mathbf{A}^3)^9 + (\mathbf{A}^3)^{10} \mathbf{A} + (\mathbf{A}^3)^{13} \mathbf{A} \\ &= (-\mathbf{I})^9 + (-\mathbf{I})^{10} \mathbf{A} + (-\mathbf{I})^{13} \mathbf{A} \\
 &= -\mathbf{I} + \mathbf{A} - \mathbf{A} \\ &= -\mathbf{I} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "real mat"
assumes h0 : "A = list_of_list_to_matrix [[3, 7], [-1, -2]]"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. A powr n = (list_of_list_to_matrix [[-1, 0], [0, -1]])"
shows  "A powr 27 + A powr 31 + A powr 40 = list_of_list_to_matrix [[-1, 0], [0, -1]]"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given a 2x2 matrix $A = \begin{pmatrix} 3 & 7 \\ -1 & -2 \end{pmatrix}$, it is known that $A^n = \begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$ for all $n$. Find the value of $A^{27} + A^{31} + A^{40}$. The final answer is $\begin{pmatrix} -1 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 \end{pmatrix}$.
